gurmukhi: srb qIrQ pir pwvr bwNDw ]AMnCyqR Gr Gr mY swNDw ]AwswvMq khUM koeI AwvY ]qqiCn muK mMgY so pwvY ]162]
transliteration: Sarab Teerath Par(i) Paavar Baandhaa|| Annchhetra Ghar Ghar Mai Saandhaa|| Aasaavant Kahoon Kaiaavaee|| Tatchhin Moukh Manad So Paavai||162||
translation: He got built places for drinking water at all the pilgrim-stations and stores of corn in every home, so that if anyone comes with any desire, he may be able to obtain the desired thing.162.

gurmukhi: BUK nwNg kyeI rhn n pwvY ]BUpq huAY kir rMk isDwvY ]bhur dwn kh krn pswrw ]eyk bwr rGurwj inhwrw ]163]
transliteration: Bhookh Naan Koirahan Na Paavai|| Bhoopat Huaikar(i) Rank Sighaavai|| Bahur Daan Kah Karan Pasaaraa|| Ek Baar Raghuraaj Nihaaraa||163||
translation: Nobody should remain hungry or naked and any beggar who came, may return like a king; the king Raghu had such administration that anyone, who would see him once, he would become able to bestow charities himself on others.163.

gurmukhi: s√çrx dwn dy ibbD pRkwrw ]rukm dwn nhI pwXq pwrw ]swj swj bhu dIny bwjw ]jn sB krY rMk rGu rwjw ]164]
transliteration: Svaran Daan De Bibadh Prakaaraa|| Roukam Daan Nahipaayat Paaraa|| Saaj Saaj Bahu Deene Baajaa|| Jan Sabh Darai Rank Raghu Raajaa||164||
translation: He gave gifts of gold and silver in various ways; he gave so much to everyone that the recipient became like a king form the status of poor.164.

gurmukhi: hsq dwn Aru austin dwnw ]gaU dwn iBDvq ieSnwnw ]hIr cIr dy dwn Awpwrw ]moih sBY mih mMfl fwrw ]165]
transliteration: Hasat Daan Ar(u) Oustan(i) Daanaa|| Gado Daan Bidhvat Ishnaanaa|| Heer Cheer De Daan Aapaaraa|| Moh(i) Sabhai Maih Maaadal Daaraa||165||
translation: He would take bath according to Shastric injunctions and then give gifts of elephants, camels and cows; by bestowing gifts of various types of garments, he had fascinated the whole earth.165.

gurmukhi: bwjI dyq gjn ky dwnw ]BwNq BwNq dInn snmwnw ]dUK BUK kwhU n sMqwvY ]jo muK mwNgY vh bru pwvY ]166]
transliteration: Baajidet Gadan Ke Daanaa|| Bhaant Bhaant Deenam Sanmaanaa|| Dookh Bhookh Kaahoo Na Santaavai|| Jo Moukh Maanht Vah Bar(u) Paavai||166||
translation: By honouring various types of the lowly, he gave horses and elephants in charity; none was afflicted with suffering and hunger and whosoever asked with suffering and hunger and whosoever asked for anything, he obtained the same.166.

gurmukhi: dwn sIl ko jwn phwrw ]dieAw isMD rGurwj BuAwrw ]suMdr mhwN DnuK Dr AwCw ]jn Ailpn ckwC qn kwCw ]167]
transliteration: Daan Seel Ko Jaan Pahaaraa|| Daiaa Sindh Raghuraaj Bhuraaraa|| Soundar Mahaan Dhanoukh Dhar Aachhaad| Jan Alipan Chakaadhh Tan Kaadhhaa||167||
translation: The king Raghu was the abode of charity and gentleness and an ocean of mercy on this earth; he was a great and expert archer and a glorious king, always remaining detached.167.

gurmukhi: inq auiT krq dyiv kI pUjw ]PUl gulwb kyvVw kUjw ]crn kml inq sIs lgwvY ]pUjn in`q cMfkw AwvY ]168]
transliteration: Nit Outh(i) Karat Dev(i) Kipoojaa|| Phool Gulaab Kevdaa Koojaa|| Charan Kamal Nit Sees Lagadvai|| Poojan Nitt Channdakaa Aavai||168||
translation: He always worshipped the goddess with roses, pandanus and sugar-candyy; and while worshipping, he touched her lotus-feet with his head.168.

gurmukhi: Drm rIq sB TOr clweI ]jqR qqR suK bsI lugweI ]BUK nwNg koeI khU n dyKw ]aUc nIc sB DnI bsyKw ]169]
transliteration: Dharam Reet Sabh Thaur Chadhaaee|| Jatra Tatra Souch Basilougadee|| Bhookh Naan Kaikahoo Na Dekhaa|| Ooch Neech Sabh Dhanibasekhaa||169||
translation: He introduced the religious traditions at all places and all the people lived peacefully everywhere; there did not seem to be any hungry and naked, high and low and everyone seemed to be a self-sufficient person.169.

gurmukhi: j`h q`h Drm Dujw PhrweI ]cor jwr nh dyK idKweI ]j`h q`h Xwr cor cun mwrw ]eyk dys khU rhY n pwrw ]170]
transliteration: Jabh Tabh Dharma Dhujaa Phahraaee|| Chor Jaar Nah Dekh Dikhaaee|| Jahh Tahh Yaar Chor Choun Maaraa|| Ek Des Kahoo Rahai Naa Paaraa||170||
translation: The religious banners fluttered everywhere and there seemed to be no thief or Thug anywhere; he had picked up and killed all the thieves and Thugs and had established one-canopy kingdom.170.

gurmukhi: swD cor koeI idSt n pyKw ]AYs rwj rGurwj ibsyKw ]cwro idSw ckR PhrwvY ]pwpn kwit mUMf iPr AwvY ]171]
transliteration: Saadh Chor Koidisht Na Pekhaa|| Ais Raaj Raghuraaj Bisekhaa|| Chdaro Dishaa Charka Phahraavai|| Paapan Kaattee Moondd Phir Aavai||171||
translation: The kingdom of king Raghu was such that the differentiation of a saint and a thief did not exist there and all were saits; his discus fluttered in all the four directions, which returned only on cutting the heads of the sinners.171.

gurmukhi: gwie isMG kh dUD iplwvY ]isMG gaU kh Gwsu cugwvY ]cor krq Dn kI Kvwrw ]qRws mwr koeI hwQu n fwrw ]172]
transliteration: Gade Singh Kah Doodh Pilaavai|| Singh Gado Kah Ghaas(u) Chougadvai|| Chor Karat Dhan Kirakhvaaraa|| Traas Maar Koihaath(u) Na Daaraa||172||
translation: The cow caused the lion to drink milk and the lion supervised the cow while grazing; the persons considered to be thieves now protected the wealth and none committed any wrong act because of the fear of punishment.172.

gurmukhi: nwr purK sovq iek syjw ]hwQ pswr n swkq ryjw ]pwvk GiRq iek Taur Kwey ]rwj qRws qy FrY n pwey ]173]
transliteration: Naar Purakh Sovat Ik Saaja|| Haath Pasaar Na Saakat Rejaa|| Paavak Ghrit Ik Thaur Rakhaae|| Raaj Traas Te Ddarai Na Paae||173||
translation: The men and women slept peacefully in their beds and none begged for anything from others; the ghee and fire lived at the same places, and did not damage each other because of the fear of the king.173.

gurmukhi: cor swD mg eyk isDwrY ]qRws qRsq kr koeI n fwrY ]gwie isMG iek Kyq iPrwhI ]hwQ clwie skq koeI nwhI ]174]
transliteration: Bhor Saadh Mag Ek Sidhaaraee|| Traas Trasat Kar Kaina Darai|| Gade Singh Ik Khet Phiraahee|| Haath Chadhaae Sakat Kainaahee||174||
translation: The thief and saints moved together and none frightened any fear because of the fear of the administration; the cow and the lion moved freely in the same field and no power could harm them.174.

gurmukhi: ieh ibiD rwju krXo rGurwjw ]dwn inSwn chUM ids bwjw ]cwro idSw bYT Kvwry ]mhwbIr Aru rUp auijAwry ]175]
transliteration: Eh Bidh(i) Raaj(u) Daryo Raghuraajaa|| Daan Nishaan Chahoon Dis Baajaa|| Chdaro Dishaa Baith Rakhvdare|| Mahaabeer Ar(u) Roop Ujidare||175||
translation: The king Raghu ruled in this way and the fame of his charity spread in all the four directions; the mighty and elegant warriors protected him in all the four directions.175.
